page.html:
‚ö∞Ô∏è Babylonian Afterlife

babylonian concept
The Babylonian underworld was a dark, dreary realm beneath the earth where all the dead dwelled regardless of their deeds in life. A place of dust and darkness, ruled by the fearsome goddess Ereshkigal and her consort Nergal, from which no mortal could return. Here the dead existed as shadowy echoes, stripped of vitality, clothed in feathers like birds, eating dust and clay.

Akitu

babylonian ritual
The Babylonian New Year Festival - A twelve-day celebration of cosmic renewal, royal legitimation, and the victory of order over chaos through the annual reenactment of Marduk's triumph over Tiamat.

page.html:
Bodhi Tree

buddhist herb
The sacred fig tree (Ficus religiosa) under which Siddhartha Gautama attained enlightenment and became the Buddha. The original tree in Bodh Gaya is one of Buddhism's most sacred sites, representing the axis mundi of Buddhist cosmology.

page.html:
Buddhist Mythology

buddhist concept
An enlightened being who delays entry into final nirvana in order to help all sentient beings achieve liberation. The bodhisattva ideal is central to Mahayana Buddhism. Major bodhisattvas include Avalokiteshvara (compassion) and Manjushri (wisdom).

page.html:
Ragnarok

üî±
norse event
Ragnarok (Old Norse Ragnar√∂k, 'Fate of the Gods') is the prophesied apocalyptic event in Norse mythology - a cataclysmic series of events including a great battle, natural disasters, and the submersion of the world in water. It culminates in the death of major gods (Odin, Thor, Freyr, Tyr), the destruction of the cosmos, and eventual renewal with a new world rising from the waters.
